articles.headline: Japan Recycles Minerals From Used Electronics
articles.snippet: Recent problems with Chinese supplies of rare earths have sent Japanese traders and companies in search of alternative sources.
articles.abstract: Recent problems with Chinese supplies of rare earths have sent Japanese traders and companies in search of alternative sources.

articles.headline: U.S. Reaches Deal in Credit-Card Antitrust Suit
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has a proposed deal with two of three companies it sued for anticompetitive practices.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has a proposed deal with two of three companies it sued for anticompetitive practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers may see more discounts for using cash instead of a credit card under a tentative deal announced Monday by the Justice Department and the credit card companies Visa and MasterCard.

articles.headline: 2 E-Books Cost More Than Amazon Hardcovers
articles.snippet: E-book readers are used to paying less, but new titles from Ken Follett and James Patterson have bucked that trend.
articles.abstract: E-book readers are used to paying less, but new titles from Ken Follett and James Patterson have bucked that trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Readers of e-books may not be able to turn paper pages, lend their copies to friends or file them away on living room bookshelves. But they do have the comfort of knowing that they paid less for them than for hardcovers.

articles.headline: After Growth, Fortunes Turn for Monsanto
articles.snippet: Monsanto, the giant of agricultural biotechnology, has been buffeted by setbacks this year that have prompted analysts to question whether its winning streak is coming to an end.
articles.abstract: Monsanto, the giant of agricultural biotechnology, has been buffeted by setbacks this year that have prompted analysts to question whether its winning streak is coming to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: As recently as late December, Monsanto was named “company of the year” by Forbes magazine. Last week, the company earned a different accolade from Jim Cramer, the television stock market commentator. “This may be the worst stock of 2010,” he proclaimed.

articles.headline: Breaking Even on A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The official managing A.I.G.’s bailout bets that investors will finally pack into the stock once they understand the government’s plan to exit its investment over time.
articles.abstract: The official managing A.I.G.’s bailout bets that investors will finally pack into the stock once they understand the government’s plan to exit its investment over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I really didn’t know what I was walking into,” Jim Millstein says about taking one the biggest jobs of his life: unraveling the taxpayers’ bailout — er, investment — in the American International Group.

articles.headline: Young Soldier Both Revered and Reviled
articles.snippet: Sgt. Calvin Gibbs’s family and friends cannot believe that he was the ringleader in the murders of Afghan civilians.
articles.abstract: Sgt. Calvin Gibbs’s family and friends cannot believe that he was the ringleader in the murders of Afghan civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: BILLINGS, Mont.  Staff Sgt. Calvin Gibbs called to say he did not kill Afghan civilians for the thrill of killing. Nor did he toss severed fingers at the feet of his fellow soldiers to scare them into silence.

articles.headline: Cities in Debt Turn to States, Adding Strain
articles.snippet: A growing number of towns and cities are seeking refuge in programs that many states provide as alternatives to federal bankruptcy court.
articles.abstract: A growing number of towns and cities are seeking refuge in programs that many states provide as alternatives to federal bankruptcy court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harrisburg, the capital of Pennsylvania, dodged financial disaster last month by getting money from the state to make a payment to its bondholders.

articles.headline: New Fuel for Local Papers: Medical Marijuana Ads
articles.snippet: Medical marijuana has been a boon for local newspapers looking for ways to cope with the flight of advertising.
articles.abstract: Medical marijuana has been a boon for local newspapers looking for ways to cope with the flight of advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — When it hit the streets here last week, the latest issue of ReLeaf, a pullout supplement to The Colorado Springs Independent devoted to medical marijuana, landed with a satisfying thud.

articles.headline: Rogue Trader at Société Générale Gets 3 Years
articles.snippet: Jérôme Kerviel was sentenced to at least three years in prison and ordered to repay the bank close to $7 billion.
articles.abstract: Jérôme Kerviel was sentenced to at least three years in prison and ordered to repay the bank close to $7 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — When a French judge on Tuesday sentenced Jérôme Kerviel, the former Société Générale trader, to three years in prison and ordered him to repay €4.9 billion in restitution to the bank, the collective gasp from the courtroom clearly signaled that the question of who bears responsibility for banks’ aggressive risk-taking in the build-up to the global financial crisis is far from resolved.
